values.description:
ODE : 

  * avoid memory leaks in case of repeated call to `setProvideFeedback(true)`

Bullet :

* fix setProvideFeedback : calling `setProvideFeedback(true)` did not allocate the necessary `BulletJoint::feeback`, resulting in a segmentation fault at the first simulation step. 
  * avoid memory leaks in case of repeated call to `setProvideFeedback(true)`
  * properly delete `BulletJoint::feeback` in destructor
values.title: Fix setProvideFeedback in ODE and Bullet

summary.raw:
ODE : 

  * avoid memory leaks in case of repeated call to `setProvideFeedback(true)`

Bullet :

* fix setProvideFeedback : calling `setProvideFeedback(true)` did not allocate the necessary `BulletJoint::feeback`, resulting in a segmentation fault at the first simulation step. 
  * avoid memory leaks in case of repeated call to `setProvideFeedback(true)`
  * properly delete `BulletJoint::feeback` in destructor
summary.html:
ODE :

  • avoid memory leaks in case of repeated call to setProvideFeedback(true)

Bullet :

  • fix setProvideFeedback : calling setProvideFeedback(true) did not allocate the necessary BulletJoint::feeback, resulting in a segmentation fault at the first simulation step.
  • avoid memory leaks in case of repeated call to setProvideFeedback(true)
  • properly delete BulletJoint::feeback in destructor

values.description:
This is the code that creates a magnetometer sensor. The sensor reports the magnetic field defined in the physics engine, rotated into the body-frame using the sensor pose. 

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
values.title: Add magnetometer sensor plus test

summary.raw:
This is the code that creates a magnetometer sensor. The sensor reports the magnetic field defined in the physics engine, rotated into the body-frame using the sensor pose. 

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
summary.html:
This is the code that creates a magnetometer sensor. The sensor reports the magnetic field defined in the physics engine, rotated into the body-frame using the sensor pose.

It requires this sdformat pull request and forms part of the sensor improvement design documents.

values.description:
This is the code that updates the IMU sensor to make use of the generic noise model framework. It preserves backward-compatibility with the bespoke IMU noise elements by injecting/changing SDF so that they fall in line with the GaussianNoiseType SDF structure. .

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
values.title: Updated IMU sensor to use generic noise models

summary.raw:
This is the code that updates the IMU sensor to make use of the generic noise model framework. It preserves backward-compatibility with the bespoke IMU noise elements by injecting/changing SDF so that they fall in line with the GaussianNoiseType SDF structure. .

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
summary.html:
This is the code that updates the IMU sensor to make use of the generic noise model framework. It preserves backward-compatibility with the bespoke IMU noise elements by injecting/changing SDF so that they fall in line with the GaussianNoiseType SDF structure. .

It requires this sdformat pull request and forms part of the sensor improvement design documents.

values.description:
This is the next part of ign math integration. This pull request is long because changing public and protected functions in one class affects many other class. Functionality should not be affected.

**Changes that are made**

1. Deprecated public & protected functions that using gazebo::math.
1. Implement replacements for deprecated functions using ignition::math.
    - Some function names remain the same, but some accessors require different names.
1. Change internal usage of gazebo::math to ignition::math.


* [No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/384/)

* Works on Windows.
values.title: Ign math integration with common library, part 1

summary.raw:
This is the next part of ign math integration. This pull request is long because changing public and protected functions in one class affects many other class. Functionality should not be affected.

**Changes that are made**

1. Deprecated public & protected functions that using gazebo::math.
1. Implement replacements for deprecated functions using ignition::math.
    - Some function names remain the same, but some accessors require different names.
1. Change internal usage of gazebo::math to ignition::math.


* [No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/384/)

* Works on Windows.
summary.html:
This is the next part of ign math integration. This pull request is long because changing public and protected functions in one class affects many other class. Functionality should not be affected.

Changes that are made

  1. Deprecated public & protected functions that using gazebo::math.
  2. Implement replacements for deprecated functions using ignition::math.
    • Some function names remain the same, but some accessors require different names.
  3. Change internal usage of gazebo::math to ignition::math.

  • No gpu clean

  • Works on Windows.

values.description: The `std::to_string(double)` function has [fixed precision with only 6 decimal places](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14520309/the-precision-of-stdto-stringdouble). For my first benchmarking analysis, the code used streams, which uses scientific notation and has better precision. In 9275a85, I changed to using `std::to_string`, but I didn't realize the precision limitations at that time. I'd now like to switch back.
values.title: Modify ServerFixture::Record to use streams instead of std::to_string to get better precision

summary.raw: The `std::to_string(double)` function has [fixed precision with only 6 decimal places](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14520309/the-precision-of-stdto-stringdouble). For my first benchmarking analysis, the code used streams, which uses scientific notation and has better precision. In 9275a85, I changed to using `std::to_string`, but I didn't realize the precision limitations at that time. I'd now like to switch back.
summary.html: The std::to_string(double) function has fixed precision with only 6 decimal places. For my first benchmarking analysis, the code used streams, which uses scientific notation and has better precision. In 9275a85, I changed to using std::to_string, but I didn't realize the precision limitations at that time. I'd now like to switch back.

values.description:
I noticed that sdformat had a broken pragma when suppressing deprecation warnings (push instead of pop). Fixing that pragma ([sdformat pull request 196](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/196/fix-pragma-from-pull-request-173-push/diff)) causes a [bunch of gazebo warnings](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/13/warnings17Result/new/) in the following files:

* examples/plugins/model_move/model_move.cc
* gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.cc
* gazebo/physics/PresetManager.cc

This branch [fixes those warnings](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/15/).

Also, I noticed that some of the warnings were related to problems parsing Vector3 variables from sdf world files (#1631), so I fixed that as well. It involves handling `ignition::math::Vector3d` types in PresetManager and `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`. To be sure that it's working, I added tests for setting gravity and magnitic_field with both ignition and gazebo Vector3's. `PhysicsEngine::GetParam` can only return one value though (currently `gazebo::math::Vector3`).

Also, I noticed that `boost::any PhysicsEngine::GetParam(const std::string &)` wasn't implemented, so I made a quick implementation.
values.title: Fix #1631 and anticipated deprecation warnings

summary.raw:
I noticed that sdformat had a broken pragma when suppressing deprecation warnings (push instead of pop). Fixing that pragma ([sdformat pull request 196](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/196/fix-pragma-from-pull-request-173-push/diff)) causes a [bunch of gazebo warnings](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/13/warnings17Result/new/) in the following files:

* examples/plugins/model_move/model_move.cc
* gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.cc
* gazebo/physics/PresetManager.cc

This branch [fixes those warnings](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/15/).

Also, I noticed that some of the warnings were related to problems parsing Vector3 variables from sdf world files (#1631), so I fixed that as well. It involves handling `ignition::math::Vector3d` types in PresetManager and `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`. To be sure that it's working, I added tests for setting gravity and magnitic_field with both ignition and gazebo Vector3's. `PhysicsEngine::GetParam` can only return one value though (currently `gazebo::math::Vector3`).

Also, I noticed that `boost::any PhysicsEngine::GetParam(const std::string &)` wasn't implemented, so I made a quick implementation.
summary.html:
I noticed that sdformat had a broken pragma when suppressing deprecation warnings (push instead of pop). Fixing that pragma (sdformat pull request 196) causes a bunch of gazebo warnings in the following files:

  • examples/plugins/model_move/model_move.cc
  • gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.cc
  • gazebo/physics/PresetManager.cc

This branch fixes those warnings.

Also, I noticed that some of the warnings were related to problems parsing Vector3 variables from sdf world files (#1631), so I fixed that as well. It involves handling ignition::math::Vector3d types in PresetManager and PhysicsEngine::SetParam. To be sure that it's working, I added tests for setting gravity and magnitic_field with both ignition and gazebo Vector3's. PhysicsEngine::GetParam can only return one value though (currently gazebo::math::Vector3).

Also, I noticed that boost::any PhysicsEngine::GetParam(const std::string &) wasn't implemented, so I made a quick implementation.

values.description:
* Added step back icon and substituted existing ones with lighter versions from @spaepcke 

* Step back and multistep functionality

* Changed logic in physics/World to support log files with skipped samples. For example, The current sample is iteration 10 and the next one is 12, so stepping forward first goes to 11 and doesn't update the scene yet, then the next step goes to 12.

* There's something weird with the way logs are recorded. The very first chunk is the complete state of the world and has no record of iterations, then from the next chunk onwards there are iterations. The thing is that while playing back, you can see that from this "chunk 0" to "chunk 1", there's a big jump in the model's motions. I wasn't sure what to do about it, whether this extra first sample is needed or not, so I left it there. Thus if you start playback paused and step once forward, the models will move but the iterations/time will remain the same.

![logplaywidget3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2911854014-logplaywidget3.png)
values.title: Add step back and multistep to log playback GUI, and suppport log files with skipped samples

summary.raw:
* Added step back icon and substituted existing ones with lighter versions from @spaepcke 

* Step back and multistep functionality

* Changed logic in physics/World to support log files with skipped samples. For example, The current sample is iteration 10 and the next one is 12, so stepping forward first goes to 11 and doesn't update the scene yet, then the next step goes to 12.

* There's something weird with the way logs are recorded. The very first chunk is the complete state of the world and has no record of iterations, then from the next chunk onwards there are iterations. The thing is that while playing back, you can see that from this "chunk 0" to "chunk 1", there's a big jump in the model's motions. I wasn't sure what to do about it, whether this extra first sample is needed or not, so I left it there. Thus if you start playback paused and step once forward, the models will move but the iterations/time will remain the same.

![logplaywidget3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2911854014-logplaywidget3.png)
summary.html:
• Added step back icon and substituted existing ones with lighter versions from @spaepcke

  • Step back and multistep functionality

  • Changed logic in physics/World to support log files with skipped samples. For example, The current sample is iteration 10 and the next one is 12, so stepping forward first goes to 11 and doesn't update the scene yet, then the next step goes to 12.

  • There's something weird with the way logs are recorded. The very first chunk is the complete state of the world and has no record of iterations, then from the next chunk onwards there are iterations. The thing is that while playing back, you can see that from this "chunk 0" to "chunk 1", there's a big jump in the model's motions. I wasn't sure what to do about it, whether this extra first sample is needed or not, so I left it there. Thus if you start playback paused and step once forward, the models will move but the iterations/time will remain the same.

values.reason: Actually I'm going to decline this for now and talk with @caguero about the order in which we should do things.

values.description:
This pull requests introduces a little more flexibility to the way which coordinate frames are dealt with in Gazebo. It provides generic PositionTransform() and VelocityTransform() methods, which allow transforms between LOCAL (Gazebo X-Y-Z), GLOBAL (East-North-Up), ECEF and SPHERICAL. 

Right now the test cases have quite soft tolerances due to the variation in the algorithms implemented and those used to verify the results in the tests.
values.title: Added more coordinate frame transforms to the SphericalCoordinates class.

summary.raw:
This pull requests introduces a little more flexibility to the way which coordinate frames are dealt with in Gazebo. It provides generic PositionTransform() and VelocityTransform() methods, which allow transforms between LOCAL (Gazebo X-Y-Z), GLOBAL (East-North-Up), ECEF and SPHERICAL. 

Right now the test cases have quite soft tolerances due to the variation in the algorithms implemented and those used to verify the results in the tests.
summary.html:
This pull requests introduces a little more flexibility to the way which coordinate frames are dealt with in Gazebo. It provides generic PositionTransform() and VelocityTransform() methods, which allow transforms between LOCAL (Gazebo X-Y-Z), GLOBAL (East-North-Up), ECEF and SPHERICAL.

Right now the test cases have quite soft tolerances due to the variation in the algorithms implemented and those used to verify the results in the tests.

values.reason: I think that I can improve upon this implementation using GDAL. There are also various issues with ignition math which need to be resolved.

values.description:
Part of issue #853 - 8th [most voted](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues?status=new&status=open) issue in Gazebo :smile: (it only takes 4 votes to get there....)

Adds an option to view link frames, both from the toolbar (applies to all models at once) and from the right-click menu (all links in one model).

The frame for the currently selected link shows up opaque. Let me know if you think it is too transparent when not selected - I wanted it not to be too crowded and to have a high contrast from the selected one.

Note: not available within the Model Editor yet.

I guess there are no unexpected failures in [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/300/#showFailuresLink)

[Trusty GPU is happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/218/) with 100% function test [coverage](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/218/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_rendering/LinkFrameVisual_cc.html) for the new test. 

![linkFrames1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4161311822-linkFrames1.png)

![linkFrame2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3607242089-linkFrame2.png)

![linkFrame3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4029000073-linkFrame3.png)
values.title: Link frame visual

summary.html:
Part of issue #853 - 8th most voted issue in Gazebo (it only takes 4 votes to get there....)

Adds an option to view link frames, both from the toolbar (applies to all models at once) and from the right-click menu (all links in one model).

The frame for the currently selected link shows up opaque. Let me know if you think it is too transparent when not selected - I wanted it not to be too crowded and to have a high contrast from the selected one.

Note: not available within the Model Editor yet.

I guess there are no unexpected failures in homebrew

Trusty GPU is happy with 100% function test coverage for the new test.

values.reason: Need to merge in a few other changes.

values.description:
Video: https://youtu.be/ZmdbzgP7f2Q

Adds a widget to the toolbar with options to move the camera to canonical angles - issue #1507.

If there's an object in the center of the screen, the camera moves keeping the object in the center, otherwise it moves about the world origin.

Also removed the hard coded default view angle, so now "reset camera" goes to the initial camera pose. You can test this with a world that starts with a different camera pose, such as `sphere_atlas_demo.world`.

The pull request was getting too large, so I'm leaving behind a couple of issues:

* On ortho view, the camera always moves to the same distance (zoom) - must look into ortho projection to see what's going on.

* The final pose might not be exactly aligned with the axes - must look into Camera::MoveToPosition to see what's going on.

![viewangles.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2208455905-viewangles.png)
values.title: Move the camera to canonical angles

summary.raw:
Video: https://youtu.be/ZmdbzgP7f2Q

Adds a widget to the toolbar with options to move the camera to canonical angles - issue #1507.

If there's an object in the center of the screen, the camera moves keeping the object in the center, otherwise it moves about the world origin.

Also removed the hard coded default view angle, so now "reset camera" goes to the initial camera pose. You can test this with a world that starts with a different camera pose, such as `sphere_atlas_demo.world`.

The pull request was getting too large, so I'm leaving behind a couple of issues:

* On ortho view, the camera always moves to the same distance (zoom) - must look into ortho projection to see what's going on.

* The final pose might not be exactly aligned with the axes - must look into Camera::MoveToPosition to see what's going on.

![viewangles.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2208455905-viewangles.png)
summary.html:
Video: https://youtu.be/ZmdbzgP7f2Q

Adds a widget to the toolbar with options to move the camera to canonical angles - issue #1507.

If there's an object in the center of the screen, the camera moves keeping the object in the center, otherwise it moves about the world origin.

Also removed the hard coded default view angle, so now "reset camera" goes to the initial camera pose. You can test this with a world that starts with a different camera pose, such as sphere_atlas_demo.world.

The pull request was getting too large, so I'm leaving behind a couple of issues:

  • On ortho view, the camera always moves to the same distance (zoom) - must look into ortho projection to see what's going on.

  • The final pose might not be exactly aligned with the axes - must look into Camera::MoveToPosition to see what's going on.

values.description: Allows plugins, tools, and events to be built on windows. Fixed dll imports/exports, added windows specfic includes (mostly winsock), and fixed code style to work on windows. Everything could be built if it were linked statically, but this is not what we want. This will be fixed as soon as some circular dependencies are resolved.For now plugin and event libraries are kept as SHARED so that it will build on Linux.
values.title: Fixing windows compilation

summary.raw: Allows plugins, tools, and events to be built on windows. Fixed dll imports/exports, added windows specfic includes (mostly winsock), and fixed code style to work on windows. Everything could be built if it were linked statically, but this is not what we want. This will be fixed as soon as some circular dependencies are resolved.For now plugin and event libraries are kept as SHARED so that it will build on Linux.
summary.html: Allows plugins, tools, and events to be built on windows. Fixed dll imports/exports, added windows specfic includes (mostly winsock), and fixed code style to work on windows. Everything could be built if it were linked statically, but this is not what we want. This will be fixed as soon as some circular dependencies are resolved.For now plugin and event libraries are kept as SHARED so that it will build on Linux.

values.description:
Gazebo does not have a Battery class. This pull request provides an ideal battery model whose behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

A battery model would be useful to simulate the power consumption of a robot. The amount of power consumed by each component of a robot depends on its usage and must be carefuly simulated to identify eventual design flaws.

In the proposed implementation, a plugin can access a battery with Link::GetBattery(). The default battery model is ideal: It just takes the initial voltage value as its constant voltage value. This behavior can be changed by specifying a custom Update function with Battery::SetUpdateFunc(T _updateFunc). The current voltage value can be requested at any time with Battery::GetVoltage().

The battery handles a list of consumers. The function Battery::AddConsumer() creates a new consumer and returns a unique consumer identifier. The power load for a consumer can then be specified by calling Battery::SetPowerLoad(uint32_t _consumerId, double _powerLoad).

The battery updates itself after each simulation iteration. It takes the power loads for each consumer and current voltage value as inputs and returns a new voltage value.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the link SDF file:

```
#!xml
<model>
  <link name="battery">
    <battery>
      <voltage>12.0</voltage> <!-- Initial voltage in volts -->
      <initial_power_load>2.0</initial_power_load> <!-- Initial power load in watts -->
    </battery>
  </link>
</model>
```

At the client side, battery properties will be displayed in the property tree of a link ONLY if a battery model exists for this link.
values.title: Added a Battery class

summary.raw:
Gazebo does not have a Battery class. This pull request provides an ideal battery model whose behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

A battery model would be useful to simulate the power consumption of a robot. The amount of power consumed by each component of a robot depends on its usage and must be carefuly simulated to identify eventual design flaws.

In the proposed implementation, a plugin can access a battery with Link::GetBattery(). The default battery model is ideal: It just takes the initial voltage value as its constant voltage value. This behavior can be changed by specifying a custom Update function with Battery::SetUpdateFunc(T _updateFunc). The current voltage value can be requested at any time with Battery::GetVoltage().

The battery handles a list of consumers. The function Battery::AddConsumer() creates a new consumer and returns a unique consumer identifier. The power load for a consumer can then be specified by calling Battery::SetPowerLoad(uint32_t _consumerId, double _powerLoad).

The battery updates itself after each simulation iteration. It takes the power loads for each consumer and current voltage value as inputs and returns a new voltage value.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the link SDF file:

```
#!xml
<model>
  <link name="battery">
    <battery>
      <voltage>12.0</voltage> <!-- Initial voltage in volts -->
      <initial_power_load>2.0</initial_power_load> <!-- Initial power load in watts -->
    </battery>
  </link>
</model>
```

At the client side, battery properties will be displayed in the property tree of a link ONLY if a battery model exists for this link.
summary.html:
Gazebo does not have a Battery class. This pull request provides an ideal battery model whose behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

A battery model would be useful to simulate the power consumption of a robot. The amount of power consumed by each component of a robot depends on its usage and must be carefuly simulated to identify eventual design flaws.

In the proposed implementation, a plugin can access a battery with Link::GetBattery(). The default battery model is ideal: It just takes the initial voltage value as its constant voltage value. This behavior can be changed by specifying a custom Update function with Battery::SetUpdateFunc(T _updateFunc). The current voltage value can be requested at any time with Battery::GetVoltage().

The battery handles a list of consumers. The function Battery::AddConsumer() creates a new consumer and returns a unique consumer identifier. The power load for a consumer can then be specified by calling Battery::SetPowerLoad(uint32_t _consumerId, double _powerLoad).

The battery updates itself after each simulation iteration. It takes the power loads for each consumer and current voltage value as inputs and returns a new voltage value.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the link SDF file:

<model>
  <link name="battery">
    <battery>
      <voltage>12.0</voltage> <!-- Initial voltage in volts -->
      <initial_power_load>2.0</initial_power_load> <!-- Initial power load in watts -->
    </battery>
  </link>
</model>

At the client side, battery properties will be displayed in the property tree of a link ONLY if a battery model exists for this link.

values.description:
This fixes [issue 1536](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1536).  
The `info->cfm` should have equal length with `info->m`,  
extra rows are removed from different joint types, based on the value of `m`.  
Integration test will be added later.

values.description:
The last detail to complete pull request #1506 and sync with the [tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=apply_force_torque&cat=tools_utilities). (See longer history [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1731/rotate-force-torque-with-mouse-on-apply/diff))

Targeted at default because we're in gazebo6 feature freeze.

Back in the original pull request, the movable text used to cause crashes, especially when changing the camera angle. I haven't been able to reproduce this on this branch. Just in case, I'm working on a unit test for movable text, which will come in a separate pull request since I think it's out of scope here.

![applyForceMany.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1363805076-applyForceMany.png)

Targeted at default because we're in gazebo6 feature freeze.

Back in the original pull request, the movable text used to cause crashes, especially when changing the camera angle. I haven't been able to reproduce this on this branch. ![applyForceMany.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1363805076-applyForceMany.png)

The last detail to complete pull request #1506 and sync with the tutorial. (See longer history here)

Targeted at default because we're in gazebo6 feature freeze.

Back in the original pull request, the movable text used to cause crashes, especially when changing the camera angle. I haven't been able to reproduce this on this branch. Just in case, I'm working on a unit test for movable text, which will come in a separate pull request since I think it's out of scope here.

values.description:
The event system will segfault if an event callback removes a connection. See the updates to `Event_TEST.cc` for more info. This problem is related to https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/pull/331

I've included a small change to the ElevatorPlugin, which is needed by ROCON.

[No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/448/)

[Homebrew clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/347/)

[Nvidia clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/358/testReport/)
values.title: Fix event segfault

values.description:
# What is added:

* Multistep forwards and backwards
* Rewind to the beginning
* Forward to the end
* Drag the time indicator to jump to a specific time (seek)

# Known back-end issues:

* Multistepping is not working properly for log files with skipped samples.

* Even for good files, stepping back one step doesn't work, and stepping back 10 steps steps only 9.

* Start any log file paused, then step one step: the time doesn't change but the model moves a lot - that's probably because the first chunk of the file doesn't have an iteration/time stamp.
values.title: Log playback GUI for multistep, rewind, forward and seek

summary.raw:
# What is added:

* Multistep forwards and backwards
* Rewind to the beginning
* Forward to the end
* Drag the time indicator to jump to a specific time (seek)

# Known back-end issues:

* Multistepping is not working properly for log files with skipped samples.

* Even for good files, stepping back one step doesn't work, and stepping back 10 steps steps only 9.

* Start any log file paused, then step one step: the time doesn't change but the model moves a lot - that's probably because the first chunk of the file doesn't have an iteration/time stamp.
summary.html:
What is added:

  • Multistep forwards and backwards
  • Rewind to the beginning
  • Forward to the end
  • Drag the time indicator to jump to a specific time (seek)

Known back-end issues:

  • Multistepping is not working properly for log files with skipped samples.

  • Even for good files, stepping back one step doesn't work, and stepping back 10 steps steps only 9.

  • Start any log file paused, then step one step: the time doesn't change but the model moves a lot - that's probably because the first chunk of the file doesn't have an iteration/time stamp.

values.description:
* added gearbox and fixed joint types to Joint toolbar menu in model editor. ~~Currently fixed joint is created using revolute joint with zero limits but that can be easily updated when pull request #1747 is merged.~~ Update: switched to use proper fixed joints 

* support gearbox and screw joint specific properties in joint inspector, and extended tests.
values.title: Support more joint types in model editor

summary.raw:
* added gearbox and fixed joint types to Joint toolbar menu in model editor. ~~Currently fixed joint is created using revolute joint with zero limits but that can be easily updated when pull request #1747 is merged.~~ Update: switched to use proper fixed joints 

* support gearbox and screw joint specific properties in joint inspector, and extended tests.
summary.html:
• added gearbox and fixed joint types to Joint toolbar menu in model editor. Currently fixed joint is created using revolute joint with zero limits but that can be easily updated when pull request #1747 is merged. Update: switched to use proper fixed joints

  • support gearbox and screw joint specific properties in joint inspector, and extended tests.

values.description:
The gazebo6 branch doesn't compile ([jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_6.0-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/15/))

This was caused by a nearly simultaneous merge of pull request #1773 and pull request #1792, with the failure in AltimeterSensor.cc:

~~~
gazebo/sensors/AltimeterSensor.cc:109:62: error: no member named 'Ign' in 'ignition::math::Pose3<double>' 
    this->dataPtr->altMsg.set_vertical_reference((this->pose.Ign() +                                                                        
                                                  ~~~~~~~~~~ ^                                                                              
gazebo/sensors/AltimeterSensor.cc:139:49: error: no member named 'Ign' in 'ignition::math::Pose3<double>' 
    ignition::math::Pose3d altPose = this->pose.Ign() + parentPose;                                                                         
                                     ~~~~~~~~~~ ^                                                                                           
gazebo/sensors/AltimeterSensor.cc:142:63: error: no member named 'pos' in 'ignition::math::Pose3<double>'; did you mean 'Pos'? 
      this->dataPtr->parentLink->GetWorldLinearVel(this->pose.pos).Ign();                                                                   
                                                              ^~~                                                                           
                                                              Pos                                                                           
gazebo/sensors/AltimeterSensor.cc:142:63: error: reference to non-static member function must be called; did you mean to call it with no arguments? 
      this->dataPtr->parentLink->GetWorldLinearVel(this->pose.pos).Ign();                                                                   
                                                   ~~~~~~~~~~~^~~                                                                           
                                                                 ()                                                                         
/usr/local/include/ignition/math/Pose3.hh:345:40: note: possible target for call                                                            
      public: inline const Vector3<T> &Pos() const                                                                                          
                                       ^                                                                                                    
/usr/local/include/ignition/math/Pose3.hh:352:34: note: possible target for call                                                            
      public: inline Vector3<T> &Pos()                                                                                                      
                                 ^                                                                                                          
4 errors generated.                                                                                                                         
make[2]: *** [gazebo/sensors/CMakeFiles/gazebo_sensors.dir/AltimeterSensor.cc.o] Error 1                                                    
make[2]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....  
~~~
values.title: Fix build
